# Major Scale in D (Mode: Aeolian, Shape: C)

## Brief Presentation
The Major scale in D, played in the Aeolian mode with Shape C, is a set of notes that create a particular sound or mood in music. Understanding how to play this scale on the guitar can enhance your musical vocabulary and improvisational skills.

## Notes and Intervals
The D Major scale in Aeolian mode with Shape C consists of the following notes:
D - E - F - G - A - B - C

The intervals in this scale are as follows:
Root (D) - Major 2nd (E) - Minor 3rd (F) - Perfect 4th (G) - Perfect 5th (A) - Minor 6th (B) - Minor 7th (C)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Major scale in D is commonly used in various genres like pop, rock, country, and classical music. When played in the Aeolian mode with Shape C, it has a melancholic and reflective quality. This scale can evoke emotions ranging from introspective and somber to hopeful and yearning, making it a versatile and expressive tool for musicians.

## Songs
Here are three songs that use the Major scale in D (Aeolian mode, Shape C):
1. "Let It Be" by The Beatles
2. "Hurt" by Johnny Cash
3. "Creep" by Radiohead

Learning to play and understand the Major scale in D with the Aeolian mode and Shape C can open up a world of musical possibilities and help you develop your own unique sound as a musician.
